title: Jhin's Escape?!?!?
body: In the new cinematic, the last shot of Jhin we see is him bowing towards Camille so my question is _did he escape tho._ I feel like she was coming really quickly at him for him to react in any way but at the same time I feel like he could easily transition from his bow into a somersault forward and just escape through the purple explosions going off around them. Idk I feel like mans is too much of a mastermind to simply just bow to Camille and die  ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

Not really. I would give endless praise to Riot if they managed to give a satisfying death to one of their champions. 

Going by Jhin's release-date fantasies, the events leading up to this could well involve him putting down or severely damaging Vi, prompting Camille to intervene while Caitlyn is mourning or watching over Vi. Then a major hunt goes on as Jhin prepares to attempt his most perfect performance on the most perfect entity that is Camille.

Camille then kills Jhin, only to find out later that he believed his own perfect end could never be achieved by anyone but Camille.
I doubt Jhin would be willing to let anyone kill him without first dealing with Shen and Zed. That would not make for a satisfying denouement for his greatest nemeses, after all.

But that is, to Jhin, diminishing the all-encompassing importance of his art. He has no such thing as a nemesis, only sources of inspiration, and rude rubes getting in his way. I feel like when Jhin left Ionia behind, he also left Shen, Zed and all that drama behind him in order to pursue higher standards of art.

And then, you have the Muse syndrome. There has to be an official name for that somewhere, but basically the idea is that an artist devoted to a subject closes his mind to things that aren't his source of inspiration, and the greater the source, the more an artist could forego in order to make the pursuit of art absolute. Renaissance artists pushing themselves to starvation in order to focus on their art was a thing, if i remember correctly.

Jhin, i think, represents this pushed to the farthest. 

I'd see it like this; He heads to Piltover after hearing rumors of Vi, her vibrant and violent existence attracting his fancy as an inspiration for art. Then he executes his piece but as a result he finds a much greater muse in Camille. Thus, he dedicates his entire existence to making the perfect piece, then realizes he would never create a better piece, and includes his own life to the piece, either intending his muse to survive himself, or to blow himself up alongside her.

All that's missing is Kindred sitting in the audience, Lamb waiting for the finale while Wolf gorges himself on the troopers.

> "The work was inescapable. Together or apart, Zed and Shen would chase the clues he had left. They would follow them back to the Blossom Festival. Back to Jyom Pass. And when they became desperate, then they would have to work together again.
> 
> It would be like it had been when they were young. They would huddle together in awe and fear.
> 
> Only then would the great Khada Jhin reveal himself…
> 
> And his true masterpiece would begin."

Jhin has every intention of confront Zed and Shen again. Even in his quotes toward them in game, he says he's looking forward to killing them, and he says how disappointed he is that Zed killed Kusho because he "needed him for this production".
